DataElement.preferredDefinition: Categorization of the presence and grade of prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia or PIN with diagnostic histologic and cytologic changes in the epithelial cells of the prostate.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Specimen High Grade Prostatic Intraepithelial Neoplasia
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Related to pathologic exam of the prostate gland for changes in epithelium regarded as precursors of malignancy, including moderate dysplasia, proliferation of secretory cells, and carcinoma in situ.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Specimen; a bit of tissue or blood or urine that is taken or used for research purposes.

Concepts.definition: A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.

Prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia characterized by the presence of morphologically malignant cells lining the acini and ducts.  The malignant cells are enlarged, contain prominent nucleoli, and have increased nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio.  The malignant cells may grow within the ducts and acini in four architectural patterns: flat, tufting, micropapillary, and cribriform.  The presence of high grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia in needle biopsy is a risk factor for the subsequent detection of carcinoma on repeat biopsy.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 8/24/17 tt transferred context, added registration status and CSI per Round 5 finalization task. updated for ISO compliance

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A neoplastic proliferation of the epithelial cells that line the acini and the ducts of the prostate gland.  The neoplastic epithelial cells are confined within the acini and the ducts and they do not invade the surrounding prostatic stroma.  Morphologically, it is classified as low or high grade._A condition or state at a particular time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Indicates that a test was not performed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia characterized by the proliferation of secretory cells with irregular spacing in the ducts and acini.  Although some proliferating epithelial cells may contain prominent nucleoli, the cytologic atypia and architectural growth patterns that are seen in the high grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia are absent.  The presence of low grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia in needle biopsy is not a risk factor for the subsequent detection of carcinoma on repeat biopsy.

Concepts.definition: Prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia characterized by the proliferation of secretory cells with irregular spacing in the ducts and acini.  Although some proliferating epithelial cells may contain prominent nucleoli, the cytologic atypia and architectural growth patterns that are seen in the high grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia are absent.  The presence of low grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia in needle biopsy is not a risk factor for the subsequent detection of carcinoma on repeat biopsy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia characterized by the presence of morphologically malignant cells lining the acini and ducts. The malignant cells are enlarged, contain prominent nucleoli, and have increased nuclear/cytoloplasmic ratio. The malignant cells may grow within the ducts and acini in four architectural patterns: flat, tufting, micropapillary, and cribriform. The presence of high grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia in needle biopsy is a risk factor for the subsequent detection of carcinoma on repeat biopsy.

Concepts.definition: Prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia characterized by the presence of morphologically malignant cells lining the acini and ducts.  The malignant cells are enlarged, contain prominent nucleoli, and have increased nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio.  The malignant cells may grow within the ducts and acini in four architectural patterns: flat, tufting, micropapillary, and cribriform.  The presence of high grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia in needle biopsy is a risk factor for the subsequent detection of carcinoma on repeat biopsy.
